case_name: Ilindra Bhaskaracharyulu Gupta and J. Pandurangarao v. Andhra Pradesh Public Service Commission

facts.text: Two petitions filed under Article 32 of the Constitution by Ilindra Bhaskaracharyulu Gupta and J. Pandurangarao respectively.

anchor.surface_text: These two petitions have been filed by Ilindra Bhaskaracharyulu Gupta and J. Pandurangarao respectively under Article 32 of the Constitution and, in substance, they challenge the validity of one of the rules

facts.text: Petition No. 355 of 1961 filed by Ilindra Bhaskaracharyulu Gupta.

anchor.surface_text: the purpose of deciding the point raised by them if we state the facts only in one of them. We will accordingly state the facts in petition No. 355 of 1961.

facts.text: Petition No. 1 of 1962 filed by J. Pandurangarao.

anchor.surface_text: We will accordingly state the facts in petition No. 355 of 1961. Our conclusion on the merits of the point raised by this petition will govern the decision of the other petition No. 1 of 1962.

facts.text: J. Pandurangarao belongs to a family settled in Guntur district in Andhra Pradesh for several generations.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner J. Pandurangarao belongs to a family which has been settled in the district of Guntur in Andhra Pradesh for several generations past.

facts.text: J. Pandurangarao was born, brought up and educated in Guntur district.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner himself was born, brought up and educated in the said district.

facts.text: J. Pandurangarao passed B.A. examination from Andhra Christian College at Guntur in 1950.

anchor.surface_text: He passed his B.A. examination from the Andhra Christian College at Guntur 1950.

facts.text: J. Pandurangarao took L.L.B. Degree from Nagpur University in 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, he took his L.L.B. Degree from the Nagpur University in 1952

facts.text: J. Pandurangarao enrolled as an Advocate of the Mysore High Court in 1954.

anchor.surface_text: and in 1954 he got himself enrolled as an Advocate if the Mysore High Court.

facts.text: J. Pandurangarao has been practising in the Court in Tenali in Guntur district since enrolment.

anchor.surface_text: Having thus been enrolled as an Advocate of the Mysore High Court, he set up his practice in the Court in Tenali in Guntur district and has been practising there ever since.

facts.text: Andhra Pradesh Public Service Commission invited applications for posts of District Munsifs in January 1961.

anchor.surface_text: In January, 1961, the respondent No. 1, the Andhra Pradesh Public Service Commission, invited applications for selection for the posts of District Munsifs in the State of Andhra Pradesh.

facts.text: J. Pandurangarao sent his application on 27th January 1961.

anchor.surface_text: As the petitioner was qualified for this post, he sent in his application on the 27th January, 1961.

facts.text: Application rejected by respondent No. 1 on 25th September 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1, however rejected his application on the 25th September, 1961 on the ground that he did number fulfil the condition

facts.text: Rejection ground: did not fulfil condition in paragraph 4-A(1) of Commission's notification published on 17th December 1960.

anchor.surface_text: on the ground that he did number fulfil the condition set out in paragraph 4-A 1  of the Commissions notification published on the 17th December, 1960, by which applications had been invited.

facts.text: Paragraph 4-A(1) requires: 1. practising as an Advocate of the High Court; 2. actually practising in Courts of Civil or Criminal jurisdiction in India for not less than three years.

anchor.surface_text: The said paragraph reads as follows - That at the time when the petitioner applies  1  he is practising as an Advocate of the High Court  2  he has been actually practising in Courts of Civil or Criminal jurisdiction in India for a period number less than three years.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 held petitioner satisfied second condition but not first as not practising as Advocate of Andhra High Court.

anchor.surface_text: According to respondent No. 1, the petitioner satisfied the second condition but did number satisfy the first since he had number been practising as an Advocate of the Andhra High Court.

facts.text: Petitioner alleges respondent misconstrued 'the High Court' in para 4-A(1) as referring to Andhra High Court instead of all High Courts in India.

anchor.surface_text: In his present petition, the petitioner alleges that respondent No. 1 has misconstrued the requirement prescribed by para. 4A 1  when it assumed that the expression the High Court in that condition refers to the Andhra High Court and number to all the High Courts in India.

facts.text: Alternatively, petitioner contends if 'the High Court' means Andhra High Court, the rule is ultra vires Articles 14 and 16(1).

anchor.surface_text: In the alternative the petitioners contention is that if the expression the High Court means the Andhra High Court, then the rule prescribing the said requirement is ultra vires inasmuch as it contravenes the petitioners fundamental rights guaranteed by articles 14 and 16 1  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Respondents urge 'the High Court' means Andhra High Court.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondents, it is urged that the construction sought to be placed by the petitioner on the relevant clause in the notification is erroneous. The expression the High Court in the context means the Andhra High Court and numberother.

facts.text: Rule 12(b) provides special qualifications for appointment as District Munsif by direct recruitment: practising as an Advocate of the High Court and actually practising three years in courts.

anchor.surface_text: The corresponding rule is Rule 12 b . The said rule provides special qualifications and says that numberperson shall be eligible for appointment to the post of District Munsif by the method specified in column  1  of the table below unless he possesses the qualifications specified in the corresponding entries in column  2  thereof.

facts.text: Court holds 'the High Court' in the rule means the Andhra High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In the context, the expression the High Court must, we think, mean the Andhra High Court.

facts.text: Andhra High Court upheld validity of the rule in Nallanthighal Bhaktavatsalam Iyenger v. Secretary, Andhra Public Service Commission, A.I.R. 1956 Andhra 14.

anchor.surface_text: In support of this argument, reliance is placed on the decision of the Andhra High Court in Nallanthighal Bhaktavatsalam Iyenger v. Secretary, Andhra Public Service Commission, Kurnool  A.I.R. 1956 Andhra 14 , in which the validity of the impugned rule has been upheld.

facts.text: Under rule 1(ii) of Andhra Bar Council Rules, advocate enrolled in other High Court can practise in Andhra High Court with reciprocity.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that under rule 1 ii  of the Andhra Bar Council Rules, an advocate entered on the roll of Advocates of a High Court established by law in India, other than the High Court of Andhra, is entitled to practise as an Advocate of the Andhra High Court, provided there is reciprocity

facts.text: Impugned rule held ultra vires and unconstitutional by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in our opinion, the impugned rule has introduced classification between one class of Advocates and the rest and the said classification must be said to be irrational

facts.text: Direction issued to first respondent to entertain petitioners' applications and deal with them in accordance with law.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the impugned rule and the corresponding portion of the paragraph of the notification based on it must be held to the ultra vires and unconstitutional. In that view of the matter, we issue a direction calling upon the first respondent to entertain the applications of the petitioners

facts.text: Public Service Commission has already conducted the test for candidates including petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: We were told by the learned Solicitor-General that the Public Service Commission has already conducted the test in respect of a large number of candidates and amongst them, the petitioners cases have also been considered.

facts.text: Applications like petitioners' cannot be rejected on ground of not practising as Advocates of Andhra High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of our decision is that applications of the person like the petitioners cannot be rejected on the preliminary ground that they are number persons practising as Advocates in the Andhra High Court

anchor.surface_text: Article 14 which provides that the State shall number deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India, as well as Article 16 1  which provides that there shall be equality of opportunity for all citizens in matters relating to employment or appointment to any office under the State, have been frequently companysidered by this Court. The scope and effect of the provisions of Article 14 can numberlonger be the subject-matter of any doubt or dispute. It is well settled that though Article 14 forbids class legislation, it does number forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation. When any impugned rule or statutory provision is assailed on the ground that it companytravenes Article 14, its validity can be sustained if two tests are satisfied.

concepts.interpretation: First test: intelligible differentia distinguishing grouped persons from others; second test: differentia has reasonable relation to object; applied to find no nexus for classifying advocates of Andhra HC

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India, as well as Article 16 1  which provides that th

anchor.surface_text: its validity can be sustained if two tests are satisfied. The first test is that the classification on which it is founded must be based on an intelligible differentia which distinguishes persons or things grouped together from others left out of the group and the second is that the differentia in question must have a reasonable relation to the object sought to be achieved by the rule or statutory provision in question.

concepts.interpretation: Second limb of Art 14 classification test; no rational nexus between requiring practice as Advocate of Andhra HC and knowledge of local laws or suitability for judicial service

holdings.text: In the context, the expression 'the High Court' means the Andhra High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that this argument is well-founded. In the companytext, the expression the High Court must, we think, mean the Andhra High Court. In companystruing the expression the High Court, we must bear in mind the fact that the subject-matter of the rules is the appointment of subordinate judicial officers who would work in companyrts subordinate to the Andhra High Court and so, the use of the definite pronoun the clearly indicates that it is number any or a High Court that is intended but it is the particular High Court of Andhra Pradesh that is in view.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Context refers to subordinate courts under Andhra HC, definite article 'the' specifies particular HC, notification requires applications through Andhra HC.

holdings.text: The plea that all the rules must be considered together to test validity is misconceived; each rule tested independently.

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with this latter argument first, it seems to us that the plea that all the rules must be companysidered together is entirely misconceived. It is quite clear that in testing the validity of any one of these rules, we will have to companysider the true scope and effect of the impugned rule itself and the decision of the question would have to be companyfined to the relevant companysiderations in respect of the said rule and numbermore.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Validity of one rule independent; invalid rule not saved by valid others, analogous to irrelevant criteria like height or colour.

holdings.text: The impugned rule does not serve the object of ensuring knowledge of local laws.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Better achieved by examination; apprenticeship not guaranteed; law degree covers local laws.

holdings.text: Under rule 1(ii) of Andhra Bar Council Rules, advocates from other High Courts can practise in Andhra HC, undermining claim that impugned rule ensures local knowledge.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that under rule 1 ii  of the Andhra Bar Council Rules, an advocate entered on the roll of Advocates of a High Court established by law in India, other than the High Court of Andhra, is entitled to practise as an Advocate of the Andhra High Court, provided there is reciprocity between the Andhra High Court on whose roll he has been entered as an Advocate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reciprocity allows non-local advocates to practise without local knowledge, so rule fails nexus.

holdings.text: Loyalty to Andhra HC or disciplinary jurisdiction provides no rational basis for classification.

anchor.surface_text: Then it is urged that a person who has been enrolled as an Advocate of the Andhra High Court would have feelings of attachment for the institution of the Andhra High Court and would be subject to the disciplinary jurisdiction of the said High Court and that would afford a rational basis for differentiating the class of advocates of the Andhra High Court from the rest of the Advocates in this companyntry.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Loyalty to judicial administration uniform across HCs; disciplinary jurisdiction similar everywhere; no nexus to suitability.

holdings.text: There is no rational basis for the classification; it lacks nexus to object and is irrational.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in our opinion, there does not appear to be any rational basis for differentiating the advocates belonged to the Andhra High Court from the rest as the impugned rule purports to do. In this companynection, it may be permissible to point out that the second companydition in regard to three years actual practice might more appropriately have required that the said three years practice should be in the Civil or Criminal Courts subordinate to the jurisdiction of the Andhra High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Classification between Andhra HC advocates and others fails both prongs of Art 14 test: intelligible differentia without rational relation to recruitment object.

holdings.text: The decision of the Andhra High Court in Nallanthighal Bhaktavatsalam Iyenger v. Secretary, Andhra Public Service Commission is not correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower court erred in upholding rule as classification irrational lacking nexus.

holdings.text: The impugned rule and corresponding notification portion are ultra vires and unconstitutional.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, in our opinion, the impugned rule has introduced classification between one class of Advocates and the rest and the said classification must be said to be irrational

holdings.reasoning_summary: Violates Arts 14 and 16(1) by irrational classification without nexus.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that under rule 1 ii  of the Andhra Bar Council Rules, an advocate entered on the roll of Advocates of a High Court established by law in India, other than the High Court of Andhra, is entitled to practise as an Advocate of the Andhra High Court, provided there is reciprocity between the Andhra High Court on whose roll he has been entered as an Advocate.
